abstract.text: Create visual effects in a scene by defining a rendering technique with custom symbols.

topicSections.title: Handling Parameters for a Technique’s Shader Programs

inlineContent.text: Examples of multipass rendering techniques include:
To create effects such as color grading and displacement mapping, define techniques that use as input the color buffer rendered by SceneKit and process that buffer with a fragment shader.

To create effects such as motion blur and screen-space ambient occlusion (SSAO), define techniques that capture information about the scene into an intermediary buffer during the main rendering pass and then perform additional drawing passes using that buffer to create the final output image. The figure below illustrates the rendering process for an SSAO technique.

abstract.text: Example of a multipass technique

inlineContent.text: object, you supply a technique definition that specifies the input and output image buffers, shader programs, shader input variables, and rendering options for each drawing pass in the technique. Defining a technique does not require Metal or OpenGL client code, but you should be familiar with the terminology and conventions of GPU rendering.
To use a technique, assign it to the
property of a view (or other SceneKit renderer object) or a camera.

SceneKit treats rendering techniques—along with shaders, 3D models, and 2D art assets—as resources rather than as part of your application code. Because the effects you create with techniques are highly visual, this approach allows you to separate design efforts from development efforts and quickly iterate on creating the visual content of your app or game.
Create a technique object using the

method, providing a dictionary that defines the technique as a series of drawing passes, each with its own shader program, inputs and outputs, and rendering options. Typically, you obtain this dictionary from a property list file included in your app’s bundle resources.
and the additional tables and sections that follow specify the format of this dictionary’s contents.
A dictionary of drawing pass definitions.
Each key is a unique string you provide to identify the pass, and the corresponding value is a dictionary defining that drawing pass. See
An array of strings, each of which names a drawing pass from the
dictionary. SceneKit performs the drawing passes in the order specified by this array.
A dictionary defining the bindings for GLSL attributes and uniform variables used in the technique’s shader programs.
Each key matches the name of a symbol used in the shader source code, and the corresponding value is a dictionary describing how that symbol should be used. See
A dictionary defining intermediary rendering targets.

Each key is a unique string you provide to identify the target (used in the inputs and outputs dictionaries of a drawing pass definition), and the corresponding value is a dictionary defining the rendering target. See

inlineContent.text: What to render for the drawing pass:
: Render only the node specified by the
key (and its hierarchy of child nodes).
: Render only a rectangle covering the entire bounds of the view. Use this option for drawing passes that process image buffers output by earlier passes.
The GLSL shader program to use for the drawing pass.
Shader source code files in the app’s bundle resources directory must have the same base name and the extensions
(fragment shader). For example, if the program name is “invert”, the files “invert.fsh” and “invert.vsh” must exist.
The names of the Metal vertex and fragment shader functions to use for the drawing pass. These functions must exist in the app’s default Metal library.

You must specify both fragment and vertex shaders, and you must specify either a GLSL shader program, a pair of Metal functions, or both. If both are specified, SceneKit uses whichever shader is appropriate for the current renderer.
Definitions of input variables for the drawing pass.
Each key is the name of a uniform variable used in the GLSL shader source code referenced by the program key. The corresponding value may be any of:

abstract.text: Shader symbol definition dictionary format

inlineContent.text: When SceneKit performs a rendering pass whose
, you can use category masks to filter the set of nodes drawn during that pass. For each node in the scene (or for
, in the node subtree), SceneKit compares the node’s

options in the pass definition using bitwise AND operations. If the node’s category mask and the include mask overlap (that is, the bitwise AND results in a nonzero value) and the node’s category mask and the exclude mask do not overlap, SceneKit includes the node in the drawing pass. Otherwise the node is not rendered in the pass.

A drawing pass renders pixel data into one or more target image buffer (or framebuffer). In SceneKit’s main drawing pass, the color render target is the screen (or rather, a view or layer for screen display), and a depth render target temporarily stores the information needed to ensure that rendered surfaces appear in the correct depth order.

A pass in a custom rendering technique may postprocess the pixel data in SceneKit’s render target, generate its own pixel data for display, or render to an intermediate target to be used as input in a later pass. You specify render targets using the following identifiers in the
targets as inputs to identify the color and depth buffers rendered to in SceneKit’s main drawing pass.
target as an output to identify the image buffer displayed as the end result of a technique.
To create an intermediate target, define your own identifier as a key in the
dictionary of a technique definition. For the corresponding value, provide a dictionary defining the render target using the keys and values in
. Intermediate targets may be color, depth, or combined depth and stencil buffers. After you define a target, you can use its identifier in the
To use an image as an input texture for a pass, define a symbol of type
To specify a render target or image sampler in the
dictionary of a pass definition, you can provide either an identifier string or a dictionary with the format described in
. The options for samplers correspond to similar properties for SceneKit material textures. For more details on each, see
The render target’s pixel format; one of the following:
The size of the render target image, in points, specified in a string of format “WxH”. For example, the string “320x480” specifies an image buffer 320 points wide by 480 points tall.
The scale factor of the render target. Defaults to
specifies 2 pixels per point, so a target whose size is “320x480” is 640 by 960 pixels.

inlineContent.text: key of a pass definition defines color blending options. Blending is disabled by default for faster rendering performance. Including a dictionary for this key enables blending (unless the dictionary’s

). Color blending combines a source color (the color output by the drawing pass’s shader program) with a destination color (the existing contents of the output buffer) using specified modes and operations.
These values correspond to blending options defined by the OpenGL specification. For further details, consult the
